Definition: Toxicity is defined as something that makes someone want to quit a conversation because it is harsh, insulting, or unfair. You must sort the input statement into one of two categories: Toxic and Non-toxic.

Positive Examples.input:

Trump went back home to ask Mike Pence the same question. " Mike, answer

"I'm not sure," said Pence. "Let me get back to you on that one." He went

Comment: Until then we must abandon all attempts to convince the stupid person. This state of affairs explains why in such circumstances our attempts to know what ‘the people’ really think are in vain and why, under these circumstances, this question is so irrelevant for the person who is thinking and acting responsibly. The word of the Bible that the fear of God is the beginning of wisdom declares that the internal liberation of human beings to live the responsible life before God is the only genuine way to overcome stupidity.
But these thoughts about stupidity also offer consolation in that they utterly forbid us to consider the majority of people to be stupid in every circumstance. It really will depend on whether those in power expect more from peoples’ stupidity than from their inner independence and wisdom."
- Dietrich Bonhoeffer, from ‘After Ten Years’ in Letters and Papers from Prison (Dietrich Bonhoeffer Works/English, vol. 8) Minneapolis, MN: Fortress Press, 2010. (FINIS)

There is woefully insufficient spending on Mental Health.  Hospital beds are often unavailable because many are occupied with elderly patients who should be moved to home care facilities.  Home care facilities are full to the brim.

The Provinces and their Ministers have a lot of responsibility for the current situation and want to simply maintain the status quo on funding instead of opening their minds to new solutions.  

In addition to the Federal funding raise, the offer of 11 Billion dollars earmarked specifically for Mental Health and Home Care was significant.  Yet the Provincial Ministers turn their collective nose at it.  Pathetic.

Comment: To the Apassingok family, & especially to Chris:I applaud & envy you & Savoonga for keeping alive the highest and best of Inupiak traditions of hard work, subsistence skills & community values!   
Non-rural Alaskans & especially non-alaskans have, sadly, all lost the very close ties to the rich subsistence values of sharing & community their very own families and smaller communities once would have always understood- and would have shared with the families of Savoonga.
Long ago I was blessed enough to have been allowed to start the first Molly Hootch one-teacher school- I did so in an old shop in Savoonga. In that time & place we all valued each other, and I was allowed by umiak captains to  join with their crews on summer whaling and winter walrus hunts. Those shared times helped shape the best of who I am as a human today.
The joy of the entire community in a successful hunt & the shared effort & song in beaching the harvest, & then dividing & sharing it are unforgettable. Thank you!

Comment: Why just non-residents?  I know they have been portrayed as the bogeymen in all this (at least in Vancouver), but I still haven't seen too much by way of proof.

In any event, if it is to be a matter of official policy that housing prices are to be kept down by penalizing speculation, shouldn't everyone (foreign and domestic) be subject to it (as was already attempted in Ontario in 1974)?  Do we really want to be seen as a country that specifically discourages foreign investment?

Of course the reality is that foreigners don't vote, so it's a much easier call politically.  But if the government is serious in its policy, it should have the guts to address the problem in its entirety. 

There's already a capital gains tax on non-principal residence properties, so much of the gain is already taxed away.  Maybe 100% of the gain on non-principal residence properties should be taxed .  At, say, a 50% tax rate, that would probably discourage a lot of speculation, foreign or otherwise.

Comment: My main complaint, which I expressed through numerous emails to the Globe and Mail moderators since 2006, has been that they are extremely diligent about deleting trollish comments that are racist in nature or contain racist language but they have permitted all sorts of attacks on women using all sorts of (often coded) sexist language. I have called them on this many times and found the Globe unable or unwilling to address it. As a result, for several years, I stopped buying the Globe and shifted to the New York Times, where moderation was much better and I was not subject to attacks for expressing a political view while female. The lack of enforcement of basic decency and constant harassment of women online has turned many off of participating on discussion boards. I hope this new system leads to more respectful and civil discussions and I hope it increases the participation of women.

Comment: sloftstra,
The  Policy Options Canada article is "rubbish"?  Really?  It's main point is that that there is not enough evidence, from Canadian or international research, to say that immigration is an economic benefit for Canada.  It's not trying to conflate Canadian and U.S. immigration or economic realities:  Quote from the article:
"While that literature includes some excellent Canadian studies, much of it focuses on the US and Europe. Since our immigration situation is so different from those in both those regions, not all the conclusions can be applied to Canada. Thus, one of our goals here is to present a list of what we do not currently know for Canada but would need to know to create effective policy."

Why should Canadians buy into a policy of high immigration if there isn't clear evidence, not conjecture, that it's an economic benefit to those already here?

Comment: Regarding buying US stocks and currency risk:  I agree with your analysis of the stock and dividend values in US$ and Canadian$.   However, you do  not discuss the risk over time of changes in relative currency valuations.  For example, my Canadian stock values have depreciated 25% because  I, a US investor,  bought them when the C$ was at par with the US$.   Conversely, a Canadian investor buying US stocks at this time incurs the risk that, when he sells the US stocks,  the US$ might depreciate relative to the Canadian$, and the dividend would also lose value .
Again, it is more complicated than that, and there are mitigating factors.  But it's something to consider.

Comment: The danger here is Trump's overplay of his hand initially, and the possibility that his massively misallocated ego will drive him to direct warfare.

North Korea is an interesting international and military stalemate situation.  Not unlike going to war with Russia and China (and possibly EXACTLY like going to war with Russia and China).  No one wins.

NK occupies a geographical status that is vital to the US's biggest "enemies", and militarily eliminating, neutralizing or simply attacking it puts two of the US's biggest allies (SK and Japan) at severe risk.

So what does Trump do?  Create an environment where the yahoos of the US call for military action, while knowing that to do so, would be catastrophic in terms of life lost in other countries, and a potential re-write of international power balances.  Brilliant.

The danger is that Trump has backed himself into a corner.  He staked his personal reputation, and that of the US, upon a promise to bring "fire and fury" upon NK . . .

Comment: Competitiveness of our oil sector with the US oil sector is a bit of a red herring.  

Right now there is no sense in increasing our output by much until we have pipelines to get it to markets other than the US. Our primary output now comes from the oil sands and we do not have the pipeline capacity for it (excluding  rail which is much more expensive and environmentally unsafe). 

The US shale oil is a different, lighter grade than Canadian oil which tends toward heavy. Hence they are not in direct competition since refineries are configured to take prodominantly one or the other And cannot interchange their inputs at will.

As to opening up new areas for oil exploration, that could be problematic given the protests we see over pipelines.

Comment: So, if everyone is given X dollars a month for "free", wouldn't our market driven economy just increase prices by X? This is not a "basic" income, it's a method to drive inflation into an economy that doesn't currently have it, and the result will be that those on a fixed income will become relatively poorer. It's the same motivation from the same people pushing for a minimum "living wage" of $15/hour, which makes robots feasible, and its apparent that either the proponents haven't studied economics, or worse, have, and are actively trying to use this to transfer wealth from senior citizens to the younger generation.

If you're worried about "robots", the answer is get more education and learn to program or repair them, not dream of getting something for doing nothing.

Comment: It is difficult to know what Scheer has in mind with his 'free speech' plank.  There is an issue in today's university environments, in that they don't come up to the public's expectations in terms of allowing controversial speakers to speak. But it isn't university administrations that are preventing this; rather it is the students themselves, and often 'far left' students.  At the same time, there isn't anything in the Charter's free speech provisions to require universities to provide a 'free speech' environment, that is, a platform for any given speaker or group.  So, I'm just curious: on what particular pretext is Scheer thinking of withdrawing university funding?

He has said he was never pressured to discontinue the Russia probe. What was meant by "loyalty" or "honest loyalty" is ambiguous in the context of that conversation - certainly no smoking gun there. The President was well within his authority to fire James Comey and it has not been shown that the reason for the firing was anything other than what the President gave. Also, Trump could have asserted executive privilege and blocked Comey's testimony, but he chose not to. If Trump had anything to hide why would he have allowed Comey to testify? Again, Trump was told he was not even under investigation.

Comment: The problem is, once again, you are looking at UBI only as a cost - and ignoring the return-on-investment. You don't have to worry about how to fund UBI. It will fund itself - it makes far more money than it costs. Thousands upon thousands of long-term empirical experiments have consistently and without exception proven it. 
Right back to the very first one the Speenhamland experiment in the 1820s. After the experiment was concluded the British government commissioned a report. It was the first ever example of government using big data to inform policy. The report was 15-thousand pages long, based on over 500 interviews, compiled by noted mathematician Thomas Malthus. It utterly condemned UBI as a dismall failure -and was so influential it would (200 years later) scupper Nixon's UBI experiment despite it's own results contradicting it. 
There's just one problem - the report was a complete fraud. Malthus never even read the interviews.

Comment: The problem with these growth-istas is that they never tell you what happens after the growth inevitably has to stop.  Most of them will admit that the world is finite, that resources are finite, but they will then go on to say that there is lots of room left.  Without going into how false that thinking is, the original question still stands.  What happens when it has to stop?  Most of these mistaken individuals believe in the concept of sustainable growth which is pretty embarrassing for them because, after all, sustainable growth is an obvious oxymoron in a finite world.  The answer to the original question is collapse.  There is only one outcome from perpetual growth in a finite world and that is collapse.  To me, planning for a future where society collapses is not very intelligent.  This article could not be more wrong.  If we were intelligently planning for the future we would be planning to manage a steady contraction of population, not expansion.

Comment: Hi Trent
..." Doctrinal evolution means the discovery of more and more reasons through Scripture, Tradition and Reason to confirm belief that the original doctrines were correct. If scholars say the Church erred here and there, how can we today say what it teaches now is not erroneous"...

I understand why that concept is important to you. That concept is often expressed by many who post here.

But for me,  a limited view and limited understanding is not so much 'erroneous" or 'error' -- it is just incomplete. As time goes on and we learn more and are capable of understanding more, we add to our former knowledge and develop it. And explain why it was limited, and why it needs development.

The 'original doctrines' were sometimes limited. Not 'incorrect' – just not fully understood.

In my view, if we as a Christian Church can't grow and develop and admit our limitations of the past, we are not a Church worthy of consideration.

Comment: HiloPuna, 

Allow me to clarify your misinformation.  HB1469 HD1 SD2 CD1 specifically states: 

"(b) The board may... (1) Modify or eliminate any of the restrictions specified in subsection (a)[.]"  

What's in subsection (a)?  

"(1)  No lease shall be for a longer term than sixty-five years[.]" 

For clarity, the measure's proposed amendment to HRS 176-36 begins by saying there is a sixty-five year cap, HOWEVER, the board can eliminate that cap.  For further clarity, section (a) establishes a cap and section (b) creates an instance where that cap may be "ELIMINATED."   

You conveniently skipped over this very relevant section in your wayward attempt to suggest that Jocelyn was wrong.  She was not and you need to RE-READ this bill (or in your words, engage in some "critical reading").

Comment: Canada 2017
-
The emperor took off all his clothes, and the swindlers pretended to dress him, piece by piece, with the new ones that were to be fitted. Then the emperor turned and looked into the mirror.
-
"Goodness, they suit you well! What a wonderful fit!" they all said. "What a pattern! What colors! Such luxurious clothes!"
-
Yes, I am ready!" said the emperor. "Don't they fit well?" He turned once again toward the mirror, because it had to appear as though he were admiring himself in all his glory.
-
The chamberlains who were to carry the train held their hands just above the floor as if they were picking up the train. As they walked they pretended to hold the train high, for they could not let anyone notice that they could see nothing.
-
"But he doesn't have anything on!" said a small child.
-
The emperor shuddered, for he knew that they were right, but he carried himself even more proudly, and the chamberlains walked along behind carrying the train that wasn't there.
-

Comment: Average income for recent UO graduates is about $42K. Student loan interest rates are about 3.75%. Let's call it $40K and 4% to be conservative. 

Straight line, repaying $25K in debt over 10 years will cost about $3000 a year, or about 7.5% of income, to start off. And there are a variety of plans which can get initial payments down to $1800 or so per year - increasing as time goes on and income grows.  And there are tax credits which reduce these costs for low income people, particularly those with families. 

4-year college graduates make about $23K more a year than HS graduates, and about $14K more than community college graduates. As Benjamin Franklin said, "An investment in knowledge pays the best interest".

Comment: Government subsidies for newspapers are common in much of Europe, and this has turned newspapers into mindless mouthpieces for old-line governments. Much of important news is censored, and much of the real news the public needs is published by small-scale blogs and web pages, or by reputable newspapers outside of the governments' borders. 
Here in Canada too much of the national media already act as mouthpieces for Justin Trudeau and Kathleen Wynne. For example, as an economist I have yet to read any serious media discussion on the shy-high electricity prices in Ontario. There has been a steady discussion of this in the Toronto Sun (a marginal paper at bestand a critic of Liberals), but nowhere else. 
The elephant in the room is the expansion of the government-subsidized, pro-Liberal CBC web page. Since it is free, why bother paying for pro-Liberal "news" from other members of the media cartel? This is why the other pro-Liberal media are in trouble. --David Murrell in Fredericton

Comment: The third party liability coverage on your car is precisely premiums paid by you for the protection of other road users. If you owe money on your car, you pay for "own damage" coverage (collision, comprehensive, etc.) for the protection of the institution you owe money to. If you have a mortgage on your house, you pay for fire insurance and such for the protection of the mortgagor.

In short, the situation where "premiums are paid by one party for the protection of another party" is EXTREMELY common.

Comment: Understand it was the wife of Dick Clark (American Bandstand) who assisted in giving the man his showbiz name.  "People call me Chubby," Ernest Evans told her.  "As in Checker?" she joked. 

The ironies continued to pile up. 

Checker's version of The Twist was a cover of the R&B chart hit by the writer Hank Ballard and his group the Midnighters. Both Hank and Chubby were black--most R&B covers were performed by white artists--sometimes in a mocking send-up. The biggest hit of the Diamonds' chart run was a good example. Little Darlin' was designed as a send-up of the Gladiolas' hit in their doowop style. Wow: nobody laughed as the version by the Canadian quartet (true--more irony!) became Billboard's #3 song of 1957.

For over 3 decades, impossible to buy any Checker originals, nor of ANY of Cameo-Parkway's stars (Dovells, Dee Dee Sharp, Bobby Rydell, Orlons) due to legal disputes. Just re-recordings. The originals were finally released in 2005. Sad irony: music fans had moved on.

.

.

.

Comment: That war should have never been fought. The South had a perfect right to leave peacefully. You probably don't know but there was a Confederate Peace Delegation in Washington before Ft.  Lincoln refused to meet with them. So did the Sec of State.  
Instead he sent two war ships and a  transport with 500 soldiers toward Charleston. 
Gen Beauregard didn't think he could defend the city against both the fort and warships and that the best course of action was to take the fort before the ships entered the harbour. 
 The ships never attempted to enter the harbour. Maj Anderson surrendered the fort and he and his men were transported under white flag to the Union fleet which returned to New York. No one was killed or even badly injured.

Comment: Safety is always our number one priority with training and real missions.  As firefighters we do training burns, as swiftwater rescuers we swim in rapids, as confined space rescuers we enter confined spaces, and as rope rescue technicians we work in the vertical world.  Is risk envolved while working in these environments, yes.  However that's why we mitigate it with engineered systems, included safety factors, and top level training.  During a real rescue you can't control all of the variables that you can during a training day.  The risk of sending a rescuer into this situation that has never worked in that environment is far more dangerous than providing training for it.  Of the thousands of fire departments and SAR teams within the country that provide rope rescue, I don't know of any that don't practice with their personnel in the steep/vertical environment.  We appreciate the concern for our rescue agencies and strive to provide the best possible service we can to our community.

Comment: Yes, as does the Church.

These are called "private" revelations. They do not belong to the Deposit of Faith.

The first test of the authenticity of a so-called private revelation is consistency with the Deposit of Faith. Alleged revelations which purport to improve, correct, or supplant that Revelation are rejected outright.

The Church notes some very few private revelations as constat de supernaturalitate (evident from the supernatural), giving evidence of supernatural intervention. But they are only to the persons who receive them for direction to a particular devotion or some other purpose.

There was no concern expressed by anyone: in fact, one senior planner said that his department's approval of a 12-story seniors' facility next to two high-pressure pipelines was not only compliant with the PPS but it furthermore is "good planning" (his words, not mine).

The NEB finally agreed to let me take two of its personnel on a tour of the Toronto sites in August 2015. One of these staff was sufficiently concerned to press for the NEB to assign an investigative 'Section 15 Panel' last October. This Panel spent four days examining the sites and speaking with officials.

Comment: Thank you. Yes, we're aware of the argument that one proposal would  merely extend an existing tax, the GE surcharge, beyond the time it's supposed to expire. We totally understand that you could say that does not increase the tax rate. But it nonetheless would increase the tax burden on taxpayers significantly--by $2.6 billion over 10 years. Remember, we are scheduled to quit paying the 0.5 percent rail tax in 2027, the way you might be scheduled to quit having to make car payments once you've paid off your car loan. We're viewing extending the surcharge as similar to extending the car payments past the date you were supposed to be done making payments. We think paying $2.6 billion in taxes more than you would have to pay without a new law is a tax increase.

Comment: The cetaceans brought to the aquarium are ones that can't be released into the wild. They'd have to be euthanized, or kept in the same 'cages', but off site. By bringing them to the aquarium, people pay admission to see them, giving the aquarium funds to care for all the other cetaceans they save who CAN be (and are) released. You never hear about those, but that's the majority of the aquarium's work (and you can easily Google to confirm). 

Banning them from the aquarium won't save them from 'cages'.... it just cages them elsewhere while preventing the rehabilitation of so many others.

It seems like you want injured animals rehabilitated and released into the wild, yet this ban does the exact opposite. Is it really better to have more die just so you don't have to see the 'cage'?

Comment: Pace Governor Poloz, the Canadian housing bubble does have implications for the inflation target. Homeowners’ replacement cost made a bigger contribution to the April annual inflation rate than any other component except for gasoline. However, at 3.9%, down from 4.0% in April, it doesn’t seem to properly reflect the national surge in housing prices, even given these are lagged data, actually reflecting the difference in February and March inflation rates. The Teranet National Bank HPI had an inflation rate of 13.5% in March, up from 13.4% in February.  The other owned accommodation expenses inflation rate of 3.5%, down from 3.6% in March, while it looks impressive, also likely badly underestimates actual inflationary pressures. Poloz will never complain about this underestimation, because he doesn't want to raise interest rates and he wants to keep driving the loonie down.

Comment: I'm not certain that the judge who issued the bench warrant was sending the right message.  A failure to appear is in essence contempt of court which is dissing the judge him or herself.  As it was shared with me even if a traffic violation(s), failure to pay accumulated parking fines, etc.  Multiples of "failure to show" can get some judges "upset" and a bench warrant(s) is issued.  No one really goes to go after those with outstanding warrants, however if you get pulled over and they see outstanding bench warrant(s) you can be arrested.  Then you post bail to get released and suppose to show up at your next hearing.  An acquaintance who had a couple of outstanding traffic violations was pulled over for a traffic violation and taken to cell block and held overnight until someone posted bail.  In my opinion, it's best to make sure everyone makes sure that traffic violation(s) and/or warrants are addressed.  Just saying...

Comment: City planners in Vancouver have been trying to persuade developers to add multi bedroom condos, but new builds are very small, and still sell for well over a million dollars.  

Unlike sf detached which is showing recent flatlining in price, prices for condos and townhouses are on a double digit price trajectory. Helped along in no small part by the fact that entire developments are presold (and resold) overseas. And after completion,  much of this housing stock sits sold and empty. Despite a city rental vacancy rate of 1%.

If cities want meaningful change in accommodating working families, they have to look deeper than asking developers to kindly build larger units.  They need to examine the role that commodification of housing plays, including selling our housing stock overseas.

Comment: "The Logan Act is a United States federal law that details the fine and/or imprisonment of unauthorized citizens who negotiate with foreign governments having a dispute with the United States... The Act was passed following George Logan's unauthorized negotiations with France in 1798." - Wikipedia

There's the centuries-old Logan Act in a nutshell. To violate the law an unauthorized citizen must NEGOTIATE with a foreign government. Simply having discussions with foreign governments is normal procedure for an incoming administration.

There's no evidence that Flynn negotiated anything, nor would it have been necessary for him to negotiate anything. And given that he's a career military man and well-versed in intelligence/diplomatic protocols, it would have been near unthinkable for him to do so.

Comment: I would love to see Gluskin Sheff's methodology and data for coming up with that horizontal bar chart.   The chart clashes with a lot of the narrative in the press and elsewhere over the past few years.

And some of the data is fishy.   Although London is very expensive when it comes to real estate, you can buy a decent-size flat in a low-rise walk-up in London for a lower cost-to-average income ratio than you can in Toronto.  It will be very close to essential services and very good public transportation.   It might even be within a 1/2 hour's walk of places like Oxford Circus or even the Bank of England building on Threadneedle Street.  Try that in Toronto or Vancouver.   

Another key difference this comparison fails to capture relates to the fact that in most of these markets, the % of people who own is lower than in Canada. Comment: Focusing on the "top 100" is a false argument because it ignores the driving factor behind those movies: financial risk. Defining a director as "female" first means that there will be a different direction, and therefore not as guaranteed a profit as the traditional one.

If you have a sizable RRSP which when converted to a RRIF will force minimum payments at a higher taxable rate, would it be advantageous to delay CPP/OAS until 70 and live solely on RRSP withdrawals from 65 to 70.  That way there will be less going into the RIFF and the minimum withdrawals will be lower.  Is this a beneficial strategy or will the higher CPP/OAS at 70 counteract the reduced minimum?
Say you have $900K in RRSPs + 100K in non-registered at age 65 when you retire.  How would you minimize the income tax paid over the next 25 years (keeping below the 45k bracket)?
65 - 70: RRSP withdrawal only at 55K/year plus 20K from non-registered
70 - 71: CPP/OAS 25K + 35 K RRSP plus 15K from non-registered
This would leave 700K (assuming low growth ) for RRIF conversion
71 - 99: CPP/OAS plus RRIF minimum

Comment: Just to make it perfectly clear, the TAX CUT is not what adds $1.5T to the debt. It is the refusal to cut government spending that adds to the debt. If you have $1.5T less in revenue coming in, but spend at the same level as you would if the money was coming in, then that results in skyrocketing debt. You need to base your spending on how much revenue is incoming. Whatever comes in, then that's what you get to spend - not a dime more. That's called a balanced budget. And yes, Congress is NOT doing enough to reduce spending. Analogy: if you make $100k at your job, but then lose your job and find another one that only pays $80K - do you keep spending as though you still make $100K? If so, you're a fool. Smart people will curtail their spending to a level sustainable with their new income, like 20% less. You don't blame your debt problems on your drop in income, you blame it on your extravagant spending habits.

Comment: FYI, Ruben, "The Star-Spangled Banner" was first written by Francis Scott Key on September 14, 1814 as a poem called "The Defense of Fort McHenry," which commemorated an action in the Battle of Baltimore during the latter stage of the Anglo-American War of 1812. It actually has nothing to do with the fight for U.S. independence that having been declared 38 years prior during the Revolutionary War on July 4, 1776. It was later set to the tune of an 18th century English drinking song and renamed "The Star-Spangled Banner" at that time, and became the national anthem in 1931. The War of 1812 was an ambitiously misbegotten war undertaken by the United States in part to seize Canada from Great Britain, which was then distracted by its struggle with Napoleonic France. The war did not go well, and when Napoleon was finally defeated and the British turned their attention to North America, things got even worse for the Americans. We were very lucky that the war ended in a rough stalemate.

Comment: Jerry, I often make that same point when Hawaii's low property tax is mentioned. But in this particular discussion, that is irrelevant.  IF the question is "which tax can be raised to pay for the completion of rail?", the fact Hawaii has a low property tax rate is relevant. One of the changing aspects of Hawaii's economy over the past few decades has been how many of the luxury homes and condos are owned by non-residents. These people are not subject to the state income tax and, if they are here on a part-time basis, don't contribute much towards he GET. Raising the LOW property tax on high-end properties makes sense IF it is done wisely, with a GRADUATED increase in the tax rate rather than a sudden jump, as the City's "Residential A" tax increase has done. Caldwell decided to  hike the property tax 70% on anyone renting a house assessed at over $1 million, Those are middle-class people in Hawaii's housing market.

Comment: A couple of comments:

(1) Well-fed cats continue to hunt--to the tune of 96 mammals, 60 birds and 68 reptiles per cat/per year (Crooks and Soule--"Nature"; 1999, Loyd, Hernandez et al--"Conservation Biology"; 2013). Feeding is not a solution.

(2) If a person is incapable of getting a 12 lb. domesticated animal to stay put, said person isn't fit to care for an animal to begin with and should give it to someone who is or euthanize it.

Comment: Many people assume that their family immigrated to the United States legally. In most cases, this statement does not reflect the fact that the U.S. immigration system was very different in the past and that their families might not have been allowed to enter had today’s laws been in effect. Claiming that a family came “legally” is simply inaccurate—unauthorized immigration has been a reality for generations.
Undocumented immigrants would arrive at ports of entry (Ellis Island, etc), where they were inspected and allowed into the country unless they fell into one of these excluded categories: prostitutes, paupers, polygamists, persons with “dangerous and loathsome contagious disease,” persons likely to become a public charge, pregnant women, anarchists, radicals, the “feebleminded” and “insane,” and the illiterate.
The vast majority of people who arrived at a port of entry had no documentation (undocumented immigrants) but were allowed to enter. Over 90% of Italians fit this category.

Comment: When I saw the  headline, I finally did the calculation - a tip of 13.27% on the after-tax amount is equivalent to 15% pre-tax. For example on a $10 food bill, the tip should be $1.50. The total should be $10 + $1.30 HST + $1.50 tip = $12.80. The tip based on the tax included amount is $1.50/11.30 = 13.27%.

Comment: I don't think the point of this system is to try to "weed out the people that [whoever] doesn't like" — it's to improve the social climate so that people can discuss things like reasonable adults, even when they strongly disagree, instead of  throwing insults at each other like a bunch of two-year-olds who aren't quite diaper trained throwing tantrums & the contents of what should be in their diapers at each other.

It's not to weed out people. It's to weed out childish insult sharing, in the hopes that maybe we can even learn things from each other even when we disagree. I like when people with different points of view can get together and talk, & sometimes even change each others minds.  But people don't often convince me of the rightness of their point of view if they're busy hurling insults.

Which is what the comment section used to be like too much of the time. So I welcome this new system, at least to give it a try. Time will tell.

Comment: It wasn't just the Conservative government's April 2015 budget that projected a surplus for 2015-16. The Parliamentary Budget Officer (PBO), who has no reason to favour the Government or the Opposition in his forecasts, still projected a $1.2-billion surplus on December 1, still based on the Conservative government’s budget measures, although the Liberals were now in office. It is notable that the PBO projected, by my estimate, about $115.2B in direct program expenditures for 2015-16 on December 1, as opposed to the actual estimate from the annual financial report of $122.1B, a difference of $6.9B, some of which could be ascribed to policy changes under the new government. So on balance it seems probable that the Conservatives would have obtained their surplus in 2015-16 if they had remained in power, although it is something that the Liberal government will never concede.

As for the company holding shares of another company, that is a legal means of tax avoidance in Canada.



nelligan.ca/article/understanding-holding-companies/

A holding company is a company that owns shares in another company. If the holding company owns the majority of shares of another company, it is also referred to as a parent company. It generally does not produce goods or services itself. The sole purpose of a holding company is usually to own shares in another company.

Comment: For several years after retiring from teaching, I worked as a field representative for the U.S. Census bureau, visiting a representative sample of addresses to collect data about whomever lived there.  I visited numerous care homes, especially in Pearl City and Waipahu, where nearly all of the care homes were owned by Filipino families.  I had only the address; so my first visit was always unannounced.  Most of the homeowners were friendly and cooperative, but it was surprising how many were hostile or afraid of me -- not because I'm nasty, haole, or have a beard, but because they feared I might be an undercover inspector for the Dept. of Health.  Why were they suspicious and afraid of an unannounced inspection?  Either because they were unlicensed, operating illegally; or because they were providing substandard care.  Most seemed OK to me; I'd be willing to live there.  But the state must improve licensing, inspections, and public reporting of results.

Comment: Half a billion dollars would go a long ways towards building a 21st century transportation system, which seems much wiser than diddling with a failed mid-twentieth century failed system. Even California has massively ramped up its light rail, passenger rail and bike infrastructure over the past twenty years while we've been building ever more freeway bridges.

We need to focus on moving people, not cars. There's just no way to move everyone everywhere in a car without paving the entire state and dispersing all activities. That's not going to happen, so Oregon needs to finally realize a couple of things:
1. Most people live and/or work in cities
2. Cities work best with complete transit systems and bike and ped networks that are also complete and safe.
3. If most of our public space is asphalt, we've failed completely and utterly in every way.

Comment: Do you understand that the books are not about "profanity, sex, violence, abuse, rape, and incest?" 

Theses are books that help people view the world in a different way. The Color Purple is an amazing book about a woman who is oppressed in the American South and yes, she is raped. But the book is about more than that - it's about sisterhood and poverty and her relationship with God. The book is an interesting example of a different type of writing - The story is written in letters and as the main character matures and learns the writing becomes better. 

The Catcher in the Rye is about holding on to adolescence and I honestly don't remember much about sex, violence, rape, or incest, but it's been a really long time since I've read it. 

The Kite Runner is an excellent book for the time we live in. It's themes are not tied to the culture and while there is a horrific rape, I think the importance of this book and it's themes of redemption and family overpower the graphic imagry.

Comment: The more healthy people there are in the risk pool, the better it is for everyone. I'm in the individual market, pay a ton for minimal insurance (I'm older) and don't receive a subsidy. The reality is that many, if not most, healthy people in the individual market that currently get a subsidy simply could not, and would not, pay the current premiums without a subsidy. If the current subsidies went away, those with high cost medical conditions would probably drain down their savings or borrow money to continue paying the premiums. That leads to a catastrophic market failure. You can't have a pool made up of only those with cancer and diabetes, and those with enough income and assets that they won't risk not having insurance, no matter what the cost. It simply will not work. You need healthy people of all income levels in the pool, and that means providing subsidies. That's the reality of our insurance based system. The current subsidies limit insurance cost to a certain % of income.

Comment: This is  an ideal spot to place 40ft shipping containers as apartments. 1st cut a large hole (big enough to drive a car thru) in the middle. Weld the doors at the end closed. Weld a set of steel bunk beds in the far ends. Weld a set of lockers next to the beds. Add a steel table and chairs. If you have to use lag bolts than weld the heads of the lag bolts. These have to be crowbar proof and sledge hammer resistant. Finally weld a steel bar one foot down from the top by the opening in the container (for ventilation) and hang a blanket or drapes for privacy. Each container will provide two apartments for two occupants each. Most contractors could provide these for about $5,000-$10,000 each. But the city of Portland would insist on paying 100's of thousands of dollars each. Just look at how much they spent on the two storage containers for homeless daytime storage use, ($226,000) each!

Comment: Mahalo, Rui, for your continuing coverage of this issue. Resolutions citing key local values are now moving forward in both the Legislature and Honolulu City Council. Support for them is strong. The more clearly we articulate who we are and learn about basic U.S. constitutional principles, the easier and more necessary it becomes to be pono.

Actually, no one is "balking at cooperating with the crackdown on criminal immigrants." Instead, cities, counties and states across America are balking at illegal practices used by the federal government to crack down mean-spiritedly on undocumented immigrants as a whole.

Overstaying one's visa is not a crime. However, warrantless holds violate the Fourth Amendment. Commandeering local law enforcement to pursue federal matters violates the Tenth Amendment, and so does withholding state funding as a punitive tactic. It is these measures that do not match our values, which remain steadfast and are being embraced now with vigor greater than ever.

Comment: Once again an article that encourages an increase in GDP but does not mention the fact that a change in GDP does not change living conditions. And living conditions should surely be our concern. And an increase in GDP suggests an increase in pollution.   

There is correlation between inequality of income (top 20% versus bottom 20% of work force) and living conditions. The lower the inequality the better the living conditions. This holds across 22 nations so it is well worth pursuing income inequality rather than GDP.

The most interesting while being controversial is Japan. A basket case economically and tied with Sweden as the best place to live. Both countries, especially Japan, have relatively homogeneous populations. 

Pursuing income inequality seems like a good idea. Everyone gains since living conditions improve.

Comment: All our roadways are getting busier. A small part of this is caused by so many former cyclists who have returned to their cars (30% since 2009). However, our population is growing and the long decline in per capita miles driven reversed itself five years ago, so we have more people, more of those people are driving and those drivers are driving more miles.

Unfortunately, unless we take steps to make other means of transportation more inviting, we know where this ends: complete congestion. After we gridlock our roads, the political price to take back space for transportation choices that move people more efficiently will be higher, but at some point we will have to bite the bullet. Hopefully by then we will have transportation planners and other city staff who do a better job than they currently do.

Comment: Re what Jesus knew, and what he may have thought about himself, as questions inviting division among Christians: I remember a very fun episode of Oprah Winfrey's program (which my late mother used to watch, and I joined her this time with great interest) in 1988, around the time of the release of Martin Scorsese's "The Last Temptation of Christ." She had on her stage three men of the cloth, a Baptist (who had grave reservations about the film), a Lutheran, and a Catholic (both of whom thought it was a grand thing and quite orthodox). Their explanations and conversation were quite entertaining, and became even more so when Oprah opened it to questions from the audience, and a Greek Orthodox priest stood up and condemned the film as blasphemous. There ensued between that priest and the Catholic priest an exchange that could have taken place in the 5th century: "He has one hypóstasis!" "Yes, but two phýseis!"

Comment: Objectively, of course, it depends on the specific community, and on the specific individuals one looks at.  At least you use qualifiers like "few" - although that appears more based on your assumptions than on  actual study of statistically valid data.   Indeed, change is inevitable, and comfortable or not, people and communities (and our state) are going to have to come to terms with it.  If urban Alaskans have one general flaw, it is the failure to grasp how "equal funding" isn't equal in effect (say for education on a per pupil basis).   In fact, there is a limit - it is too inefficient to build a school for a handful of students - so the state won't.  We may have to re-define where the line is drawn.  But it is impossible to get the same result for $x in a small, rural place as we get in Anchorage.  People everywhere must be realistic, and make choices inside reasonable parameters.

Comment: Yes, we have had this discussion. CFLs didn't "languish". They sold by the millions.   They also had shortcomings that many consumers didn't like. Comment: Two points: Mr. Porter uses the word "disproven" with respect to the “5 year / 50%" saying. Nothing is proven or disproven in social science, let alone by one study. Never. The retention study cited was seriously flawed in that it began during the deep recession at the end of the Bush presidency when most of us were happy to have and keep any job.   

Secondly: Mr. Wang’s experience is typical for TFA teachers. Many use this two-year public service commitment to help their nation and strengthen their vitae. Education Week, Oct 4, 2011 reported that after five years, only 27.8% of the TFA teachers were still in teaching. 
TFA teachers are often viewed as well-intentioned and inexperienced. By the time they gain experience, they move on to their primary job, like Mr. Wang. Struggling schools can use beginning teachers, sure, I’ve never heard an administrator wish for a constant supply of well-intentioned beginning teachers with only 5 WEEKS of teaching preparation.

Comment: You're right, I hadn't looked into MOA's ordinance. Thanks for pointing that out.

Forfeiture only occurs with more than one prior DUI, however. That seems reasonable in that the Constitutional support for asset forfeiture comes from preventing continued unsafe use--if someone has had multiple DUI's then there's a reasonable expectation that the vehicle will be used unsafely in the future. This rule doesn't seem applicable to support the seizure of private property for a first-time speeding violation, however, as without repeat offense there isn't a credible reason to believe that specific deterrence has failed to prevent a repeat offense. 

Also, I'm still curious about "you don't know" comment. Do you really have so little to contribute to the conversation that you come out with that? Try harder.

Comment: Fine, then would you be OK with a law that says that medical providers will only treat you if you can show proof of ability to pay.  That you cannot dispense with medical expenses through bankruptcy, and that you must sign a waiver stating that if you choose to not purchase health insurance, that if/when you get sick, if you cannot provide proof of ability to pay, that means you or your family can be turned away.  Would you be OK with that?  Personally, I am getting to the point, where I think this is where we need to go.  Take those who choose to not purchase health insurance, and make it clear that you are on your own, period.  For those too poor to purchase insurance, there would still be a safety net, for those who have insurance, but still end up bankrupt, there would be an out via the bankruptcy courts, but for those who believe that it is freedom to not purchase insurance, you would sign away any rights to be treated without being able to pay.  Would you go for that?

Comment: yes, but if you look at fact check, you would find the figures are a little different.  And I would argue that you would have more people on food stamps if there wasn't deficit spending to get the country out of recession including the bailout of the auto companies.  The number of people receiving food stamps dropped again since our last report, by nearly 142,000. As of October, the most recent month on record, nearly 45.4 million Americans were still receiving the food aid, now known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.

That’s 5.1 percent lower than the record level set in December 2012, but still nearly 42 percent higher than it was when Obama took office in 2009.

But as we noted when Republicans called Obama the “Food Stamp President,” 14.7 million people were added to the food-stamp rolls during George W. Bush’s time in office. By comparison, the net gain under Obama now stands at just under 13.4 million — and it’s slowly declining as the economy improves.

Comment: "To be clear, the regime of Bashar al-Assad has itself transgressed most bounds of international law and human morality – most notoriously in what Western states believe was another chemical weapons attack on a civilian population."
This statement in Craig's article makes no sense: "... has itself transgressed most bounds of..." is a definitive statement. "... most notoriously in what Western states believe was" contradicts that definitive statement, and if the basis for "the regime of Bashar al-Assad has itself transgressed..." is unproven, conjecture, mere allegation, then the statement "the regime of Bashar al-Assad has itself transgressed" is flawed, and is a false statement.
Basically, Craig is trying to skate around the reality of what is known and can be said, and re-frame it to make a damning assertion. It's basically trying to cover up that there is no excuse for Trump's act of war, and make it sound as if there is an excuse. I think that conveys a lack of morality, itself.

Comment: Unusually, Margaret, you are behind the times on this research. Yes, Implicit Association Tests are considered accurate. But if you try to see if this affects real-world decisions of those studied; the answer is not at all. NOT AT ALL, for those not listening. In other words, the IAT is an interesting tool that helps us identify the race of a subject (or other parameter if you design the test that way) but it doesn't show how test-takers behave in the real world.  It seems there is no correlation between IAT results and real-world behaviour.  All it seems to mean is that anyone taking the test recognises 'others' in the most basic sense (which may be hard-wired into their brains by evolution) but when faced with real-world challenges they easily overcome that and don't discriminate.
Even you, Margaret, have hard-wired biases. But you can easily overcome them with learned common sense and fairness. Thinking overcomes inbuilt bias. That's reality, but might not make an article.

Comment: (Part 2)  (I'll put the end of my earlier comment here, I guess, rather than waiting for the moderators.) I think people, (and particularly men) who work with children and youths, need to know that false accusations are a hazard that just comes with the territory. And more so, when the young are stressed and troubled.  It's like doing mission work, treating people with disease. You have to get all the shots, and exercise all due caution, in order to do some good. And even so, there is a risk that the very stuff you hope to alleviate snags you, too. 

People often assume that sentimental good intentions provide an immunity from doing harm, and from being harmed. Especially when children are the  objects of good will. There is a dangerous naivete, (and possibly arrogance) in that, and it is one of several points that those of us who would only help the young, and some of those who take sexual advantage, can have in common.

Comment: Spencer wrote  in his Principles of Biology, "This survival of the fittest, which I have here sought to express in mechanical terms, is that which Mr. Darwin has called 'natural selection', or the preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life." Darwin liked the phrase, as did  Alfred Russel Wallace, who had developed the theory of natural selection independently of Darwin (but Darwin published first -- after being made aware of Wallace's work). Darwin himself used it in some of the later editions of Origin of Species, meaning "better designed for an immediate, local environment".

Unfortunately, Spencer and some of his followers took the phrase in what they called a moral sense,  as an ethical precept that sanctioned cut-throat economic competition. Some of the more extreme Social Darwinists said that the poor should not be helped, since it would be aiding the "less fit" in surviving. They claimed that social caste was determined by natural superiority.

Comment: You get in the bus. The teens and twenty-somethings are sitting quietly, focused on the screens on their phones and the headphones in their ears. Those two are listening to a political debate in Washington streamed over an American TV station. The three over there are listening to a pop concert broadcast in the Hindi language from a city in India. That one is watching a BBC comedy from Manchester about a dentist with annoying kids. There are four in the corner watching a TV show in Cantonese, from Hong Kong, talking about job opportunity comparisons between Hong Kong and Shanghai.

Meanwhile, in a conference room in Ottawa, middle aged government bureaucrats are busy trying to figure out if the rules for the number of Canadian songs per hour on AM radio are sufficiently stringent, and whether a novel tax on digital broadcasts of American movies could somehow be created as a new source of CBC funding.

I wonder what dinosaurs thought when the big streak of light fired up the sky...

Comment: They largely have moved this way. Most their plans now throttle the bandwidth when the cap is exceeded instead of charging for overages... so you can keep internet'ing away but at slower speeds and without surprise charges. Comment: Pre Vatican II, the Church used pagan and Jewish symbols to express Christian ideas about God. Basilicas, a form derived from Roman political systems, became the dominant architectural pattern. Sacrifice, the dominant ritual of the pre Christian world, was used to explain Christ’s relationship to us. Christian ritual mimicked pagan rituals as the simplest way to express the Christian mysteries in ways pagans would understand.
Vatican II changed all that, to copy Christ’s choice to reach out to us in a fully human form. Pagan ritual has largely faded from our consciousness, so alternative symbol systems were adapted. The same essential mystery still celebrates that God chose us to be His sons and daughters in Christ. The family of Our Father has replaced the sacrifice of Christ as the dominant way of explaining the same Eucharist.

Comment: Two egregious lies used by Christy,Mason, and the Globe to support the Fascist effort to weasel around in the gravy.

First under the law,  the speaker makes oath to serve the parliament until it is ended to the best of his ability. To make such an oath knowing he was going to resign in a week or two is a violation of law on such oaths and would be subject to criminal sanction if it could be proved. The right to resign is not absolute in law.

Secondly there is no authority which states that the speaker can't break tie votes on any matter. It is not in fact even partisan as the speaker commits in advance to side with the government on all tie votes regardless of the issue

Section 49 of Canada’s Constitution Act states: “Questions arising in the House of Commons shall be decided by a Majority of Voices other than that of the Speaker, and when the Voices are equal, but not otherwise, the Speaker shall have a Vote.” 

 Erskine May’s definitive 1844 parliamentary practice guide agrees.

Comment: "Working class" may be a nebulous concept to those above that level, but it seriously matters to those of us in that class. It also matters to anyone who wants to understand how this country works.

There are exceptions to every rule but if you look at the research, as Robert Putnam has in his recent book 'Our Kids", in most cases economic class will make a big difference in kids' opportunities and how they come out. Putnam uses education level, high school or college, to differentiate between working class and middle class. That probably works for research purposes, although not always for individuals. I have a BA in sociology but never left the working class.

Unfortunately, there were ashtrays in the home I grew up in. I was the only member of my family who never smoked, probably because when I was 15 my mother brought home a library book with photos of dead smokers' lungs. I believe smoking contributed to the early deaths of some of them. Working-class habit. Stress-related.

Comment: Shareholder profits are fine for some things - not healthcare among many other things. The government has and should have advantages such as economy of scale, public accountability (assuming we have a true and functioning "4th estate" which is an entirely different discussion), and ability to run at a loss when it's to the benefit of the public good. The rest of the industrialized/advanced economy world figured this out long ago. Should we privatize the military for example? Massively downsize? Yes - but the growth of and the increasing privatization of that particular sector is playing with fire not only on a national scale but on an international one as Eisenhower warned us against over a half century ago. The inherent conflict of interest between the public good and private profit is a problem that cannot be resolved in any other way in my view. Great in theory not in reality though. Also I'd be careful with titles like "right of center" - these are very specious notions.

Comment: To be fair to Mr. Jenkins the Alaska State Constitution reads: "All income from the permanent fund shall be deposited in the general fund unless otherwise provided by law. [Amended 1976]. The clause "unless otherwise provided by law" was the amendment that allowed for the Statute that sets up the 50% payout from the Permanent Fund Earnings.  The other 50% of the Earnings has not been used to date to pay for government expenses.  So how can anyone argue that the Governor had to take half the dividend to pay for State expenses when they haven't been using half the funds that were already available ?  No, the People's half is not enshrined in the Constitution, but in the AK Constitution it does say that the Resources of this State shall be used for the Maximum Benefit of the People. (paraphrased)  This is the mandate that is fulfilled in the Permanent Fund Dividend.  And, no, it doesn't say that the Dividend can't be touched without a vote of the People, but if We the People are sharehold
